params.text:
Welcome to the HSHL lab safety course!

In this course, we will guide you through the important safety rules for working in our labs.

To pass the course, you need to answer all the questions correctly.

Each lab has special instructions that you need to know before using the lab. Without understanding these instructions, you cannot work in the lab.

Please make sure you follow all the instructions carefully. This helps keep everyone safe, including students and teachers.
Goals of the Basic Lab Rules:

Goals of the Basic Lab Rules:

  • Ensure the health and safety of everyone in the lab
  • Prevent accidents
  • Support effective use of the lab for both research and teaching
  • Minimize environmental impact
  • Ensure economical use of lab resources

params.alt: Access to the laboratory only with valid safety instruction!

params.text:
Permission to Work in the Lab

  • Only people who have been authorized and instructed can work in the lab.
  • Each lab has a designated professor who is responsible for the lab and its safety. You can get their contact information outside the lab on the sing next to the door.
  • This professor sets and updates specific lab rules.
  • If necessary, the responsible professor can restrict access to the lab.
  • Unsupervised experiments must be set up to ensure they pose no risk or danger.

answers.text: It is required for a student to be well instructed and not prohibited by a responsible professor.
It is required for a student to be enrolled in HSHL.
It is required for a student to be a professor.
It is required for a students project deadline to be very soon.

params.question: When can you leave an experiment unsupervised?

metadata.title: Permission to work in the lab

params.text:
At HSHL, students are treated similarly to employees in matters of work safety and health. This means you have both rights and responsibilities.

Your Rights:

  • You have the right to suggest safety improvements to your professor, internship supervisor, or other relevant contacts.
  • If internal options are exhausted, you may contact external authorities, such as management, occupational safety professionals, or staff councils.

Your Obligations:

  • Participate in all required safety training.
  • Follow all safety instructions, such as operating guidelines.
  • Refuse any task or instruction that feels unsafe.
  • Take responsibility for your own safety and health.
  • Ensure that your actions do not endanger other members of the institution.
  • Use machines, tools, and equipment safely and correctly.
  • Properly use protective gear and immediately report any issues with the safety systems.
  • Always wear your personal protective equipment (PPE) correctly.
  • Report any immediate or significant safety hazards to your contact person as soon as possible.

For further details, visit HSHL Safety Information, where you can also find information on:

  • Safety and ergonomics
  • Important phone numbers
  • Guidelines and rules

behaviour.feedbackOnWrong: Students have a right to suggest for improvements

params.text:
Base Rules

Everyone working in the lab must ensure that all necessary safety and security equipment is available and functioning. This includes:

  • Emergency exits
  • First-aid information (flyer)
  • Fire-hazard information (flyer)

It is important that all employees know how to properly use this equipment. You must not disable or block any safety equipment (for example, by placing objects in front of emergency exits).

Safety and security equipment should only be used for its intended purpose.

Let’s take a closer look at the details:
Lab L3.3-E02-110 - in the context of the lesson - you are here
After escaping the building you must procced to the collection point on the parking lot until further instructions.

To prevent the spread of fire and smoke curtains are deployed on the central stairway, making it inaccessible during a fire. 

Consult the Escape Routes and Rescue Equipment map to find the closest escape path

Do not use the elevator in case of fire! 

Consult the Escape Routes and Rescue Equipment map to find the closest escape path.

In case of a fire calmly follow the escape routes to exit the building to proceed to the collection point.

Do not obstruct or block escape routes!

If the escape route is blocked or smoky, stay calm, close the doors, and make yourself visible at the window by waving and shouting.
Attempt to extinguish the fire only if this is possible without endangering yourself. In case of strong smoke development, leave the room immediately.
Each lab comes equiped with a fire extinguisher not shown on evacuation scheeme

answers.text: Leave the building using the closest escape route.
Take the fire extinguisher and start patroling the building looking for a fire to fight.

params.text: First aid

Principles:

People in need require help. This is not only a question of morality, but also a legal requirement. We are obliged to help in an emergency, an accident - within the bounds of our possibilities. For most of us it is obvious to help people in need within the scope of our possibilities, even without being legally obliged to do so.

How to get it right

  • Stay calm. First get an overview of the situation you have found.
  • Observe your own safety, secure the scene of the accident.
  • Call for help loudly, thereby drawing attention to the emergency situation.
    Address bystanders directly and ask for their help. It is always important that someone takes the initiative. Reassure those affected and, if necessary, those around you.

Sometimes you first have to save the injured person from acute danger by using the Rautek maneuver.

How to get it right:

1. Speak to the injured person. If they are conscious, inform them of the intended action.

2. Take hold of the person lying on the floor from behind under the neck and shoulders and make them sit with appropriate momentum. Make sure that you support the head with your forearms and that the patient does not fall to the side.

3. Now step closer behind the patient and with both arms reach underneath their armpits. Place one of the patient's forearms crosswise in front of their body and grab this arm with both hands from above. Do not grab the forearm, but rake over it with all fingers (also thumbs).

4. Bend your knees and keep your back straight to relieve the spine, pull the person concerned close to your own body onto your thighs. Then pull them to a safe place and carefully lay them down preferably on a blanket.

5. Then talk to the patient again and administer the necessary first aid.

The obligation to help

People in need require help. This is not only a question of morality, but also a legal requirement. We are obliged to help in an emergency, an accident - within the bounds of our possibilities. For most of us it is obvious to help people in need within the scope of our possibilities, even without being legally obliged to do so.

According to § 323c StGB (German Criminal Code) we are legally obliged to help

"Whoever does not render assistance in the case of an accident or a common danger or emergency although it is necessary and can reasonably be expected under the circumstances, in particular if it is possible without substantial danger to that person and without breaching other important duties, incurs a penalty of imprisonment for a term not exceeding one year or a fine."

The accident report

Alerting the rescue service as fast as possible is almost always an important part of first aid.

The uniform nationwide emergency numbers are 112

The accident report should contain the following information:

  • Where is the emergency? -   Specify the exact location of the emergency: town, street, house number, floor etc. In case of our university - Hoch-Schule Hamm-Lippstadt Campus Lippstadt(/Hamm).
  • What has happened? - The rescue directing centre has to be able to identify what measures need to be taken.
  • How many injured/victims need to be taken care of?
  • Which type of injuries or symptoms do the viticms have? - Is anybody in a life-threatening condition?
  • Wait for any questions/instructions the dispatcher might have! - Only hang up when they have ended the call on their end.

The dispatcher will usually lead the conversation with a fixed set of questions.

The HSHL First responders Numbers can be found in every laboratory:

The first contact

Usually no technical aids are required to learn about the condition of an injured person. Most of the victims are conscious and therefore responsive. They can provide details about their injuries, pain or their condition. However, it must be taken into account that injured, but also acutely ill people, are usually emotionally very tense. It is therefore important to build up trust between the first-aider and the person affected.

Dealing with victim:

  • Get yourself on eye-level with the victim - Kneel or squat down when the person is lying on the floor. 
  • Look at the person - You can see if they are agitated, cold, in pain or have visible injuries.
  • Tell them your name - Ask them for their name.
  • Ask other people for help.
  • Carefully establish physical contact - Hold the patient's hand or place your hand on their shoulder.
  • Always tell the person what you are doing.

Recognising unconsciousness - The person is unresponsive, they no longer react to physical contact, such as shaking their shoulders.
Dangers of unconsciousness - protective reflexes are not functional and muscles are relaxed. Due to lost muscle tone the tounge can block the airway.
Check breathing: Clear their airway. With your cheek and ear you can feel and hear the breaths. A rising and falling chest indicates moving air, thus breathing.

1. Position the arm closest to you in a right angle to the body, the palm is facing upwards.

2. Take the arm farther from you across the person's chest and place the back of their hand on the closer cheek.

3. Bend the leg farther from you by pulling the thigh (not the joint).

4. Pull the unconscious person towards you so that the thigh is positioned at a right angle to the hip and that the hand on the cheek maintains its position.

5 .Clear the airway and stabilise the position with the hand on the cheek.

6. Cover the person and regularly check their breathing.

The Deifbrillators in HSHL are located in L4.1-E00 and  L1-E01. Have someone fetch for it immidiately in case of Respiratory and circulatory disorders.

Stick the electrodes on the device to the naked chest of the person affected and switch the device on.
It will diagnose the heart activity. Only if there is ventricular fibrillation you can trigger a shock - with voice-guided instruction.
This simple operation means that the device can be used even by tained layperson first responders.
After using the First aid kit, fill out a form in accident book so that a person affected can recieve a compensation from the School insurance:
First Responders

In case of an emergency, you can reach out to HSHL’s First Responders. They are trained to help guide you through dangerous situations.

You can find the updated list with contact information for the current First Responders in every lab, next to the internal network telephone.
Clean Desk | Clean Lab Principle

Everyone must keep the lab clean, tidy, and organized. Please follow these rules:

  • No animals are allowed in the lab.
  • Eating, drinking, and smoking are not permitted.
  • Return workstations to the way you found them (turn off devices, close windows, etc.).
  • Leave the lab in perfect condition—clean up any mess or waste you create.
  • Before using any equipment, inspect it for damage.
  • Ensure you have enough light, space, and a quiet environment before starting your work.

items.description: Poor workspace design prevents other people from using the tools and can lead to fire hazards.
Please make sure that you leave the work space welcoming and safe for other students and yourself.
If you are working on a project that you would like to finish tomorow in the lab, consider using one of numerous organisers and drawers in the lab.
If you are working on a project that you would like to finish tomorow in the lab, consider using one of numerous organisers and drawers in the lab.
If you are working on a project that you would like to finish tomorow in the lab, consider using one of numerous organisers and drawers in the lab.

params.title: Always make sure to leave the work space the same as before or better.

params.text: Rules for L3.3-E02-190
Each laboratory has special rules you need to know before you start working in the lab.
Base rules

1. All employees have to make sure that all required safety and security equipment is available and working in the lab.
  2. All employees have to keep the lab nice, neat and clean.
  3. Malfunctioning, broken or otherwise defunct equipment has to be removed from the lab immediately. This equipment has to be marked "out of order” and either be recycled or repaired.
  4. Keep lab-doors closed!
  5. Before working with hazardous substances, all personnel in the laboratory must be informed of the hazards so that they can also take the necessary protective measures.
  6. Experiments may only be unsupervised if the experiment does not pose any danger.
  7. Only authorized and trained personnel are permitted in the laboratory.
  8. Shorts or skirts are not permitted. Only sturdy, closed-toe, non-slip footwear is permitted. The general rule is: Appropriate protective clothing must be worn in the laboratory.
  9. When performing soldering work, always work in the designated extraction area and wear the prescribed protective equipment.
  10. Eating, drinking, and smoking are prohibited in the laboratory.
  11. Hazardous substances should not be kept or stored in containers that could be confused with food!
  12. At the end of the working day, the workplaces must be left in the same condition as when work began (e.g. switch off technical equipment and dismantle it if necessary, close windows).
  13. Items may only be removed from the laboratory with the written consent of the technical staff member or the laboratory manager, specifying the loan period.

HSHL offers the following cloud systems for storing your files:

  • NextCloud (2 GB) – Learn more here
  • Sciebo (5 Petabytes shared among all users) – Learn more here

Please remember:

  • Respect copyrights and patents when using these services.
  • Content that violates German law cannot be uploaded, viewed, or saved in any form.
6S Lean Approach

The following six steps help ensure productive and safe work in the lab:

  1. Seiri (Sort)
    Identify what is necessary and unnecessary.
    Remove unnecessary items from the workspace.

  2. Seiton (Straighten, set in order)
    Organize and arrange the necessary items.
    Create clear, easy-to-follow storage locations.

  3. Seiso (Shine)
    Clean and maintain the workspace regularly.
    Prevent contamination and ensure safety.

  4. Seiketsu (Standardize)
    Follow consistent procedures and work instructions.
    Keep the lab clean and organized at all times.

  5. Shitsuke (Sustain)
    Continuously review and improve processes.
    Encourage a culture of discipline and improvement.

  6. Safety
    Always prioritize safety in all lab activities.
    Identify and address potential hazards.
Repairs and Changes

• Any damage to the lab, equipment, or machines must be reported, and repairs will be arranged by the responsible professor.
  • Changing hardware or software configurations is not allowed.
  • Only the IT department is permitted to download and install software.

params.text: Electrical equipment

Common Rules for Electrical Tools

There are a few basic safety rules that apply to all electrical tools. These rules don’t cover every specific danger, but they are important to remember:

Before starting work with electrical equipment:

  • Make sure the equipment is not visibly damaged.
  • Check that the cables are also not damaged.
  • Ensure your hands and workspace are dry.
  • Make sure you have received the lab’s safety instructions and have read the manufacturer’s manual for the equipment.
  • Use the correct power sources for the equipment.

While working:

  • Follow both the lab’s and the manufacturer’s safety instructions.
  • Only use the equipment for its intended purpose.

In case of malfunctions (e.g., unusual noises, smoke, electric shocks, etc.):

  • Immediately turn off the equipment and inform the responsible specialist or supervisor.
  • Do not attempt any unauthorized repairs or maintenance.

Important:
Users are responsible for checking the safety of equipment and machines before use.

Please note, HSHL Lippstadt and its entities do not guarantee that the systems meet all user requirements or that they will run without errors or interruptions.

answers.text: To check the equipment and cables for visible damage.
To familiarise oneself with the manufacturers manuals.
Make sure someone is observing you powering the tool on.
Make sure no one is observing you powering the tool on.

params.text: Electrical equipment
To turn on the power sockets in the Lab:

items.description: To turn on the workplace powersockets in the laborotory...
Flip the leftmost switch in between the big-round and small-rectangular buttons

then flip the switch next to the two sockets you are planning to use.

You have power now!
Before you leave, make sure to turn off the power by performing the above actions in reverse
The Big Red Round Button is to be used in case of emergencies and not to casually turn off power

params.text: To turn off return the power-breakers to their initial position.
Make the equipment you are working on unavaliable to switch on, especially if you are away from it.

metadata.title: Make the equipment you are working on unavaliable

params.text: Make sure that the equipment you are working on has no power with the multimeter.

After you checked the equipment ground the 1st circuit.
That way the moment it may be accidentaly turned on, the circuit breaker would immediately switch off.
In case there are live parts impossible to switch off you should insuilate them from the workspace.

What to do in case of IT emergencies?

  1. Stay calm and don’t panic.

  2. Report the IT emergency right away.

    Don’t hesitate to call—it's always better to be safe than sorry!

IT Emergency Response Number:
📞 02381 / 8789-250

or via:
it-support@hshl.de

metadata.title: What to do in case of IT emergencies

params.text:
• 👤 Who reports the emergency?
  • 💻 What IT system is affected?
  • 🔍 How did you work with the IT system? What did you observe?
  • ⏰ When did the indident occur
  • 📍 Where is the affected IT system located (building, room, workstation)

Rules of Conduct in case of an IT emergency:

1. Stop using the IT system

2. Record your observations

3. Take measures only upon instructions

4. Turn off WiFi

5. Pull out thenetwork plug

6. Don't turn off the computer!

tipsAndFeedback.tip: Reach to the IT department and say you have important unsaved data during the emergency

params.text:
Postscript

Remember, at HSHL, students are required to:

  • Take responsibility for their own safety and health.
  • Consider the safety and health of others affected by their actions.

We highly recommend taking the time to familiarize yourself with any electrical or potentially dangerous equipment. You can do this by reading the manual or asking for help from someone with more experience. This will help you avoid unnecessary problems or injury.

Thank you for taking the time to go through the safety section and for helping to keep our labs safe and welcoming!

Resources

  • First Aid Manual: Download here (as of 02.09.2024)
  • Safety Instructions for First Semester Students:
    Basic Freshman Training – Unofficial translation of the original German document.
  • Guidelines for Laboratory L3.3-EO2-190
